name: It's A Good Thing
description: People like to admit that their bases are usually horrifically ugly. The Baby's First Base Guide recommends digging in somewhere for the beginning of the game. Those holes in the ground are rarely pretty. The thing is that making things pretty ultimately is not that hard. You just have to know what is out there. This chapter showcases some of the different common decorating and architectural mods that clean up your base and make you proud of it.

quests.name: The Builder's Wand
quests.description: This thing is hot stuff. I sometimes just cheat one in because I don't see why it should be THIS HARD to make one. Like, is it really "overpowered?" Whatever. The routine for making this involves unstable ingots using that division sigil. The necessary unstable ingot will blow up and kill you if take your time making it, so I can't put that as an intermediate step here. You have to do this in one go. So look at the recipe for the builder's wand, then look at it again. Then make a crafting table a good 20-30+ blocks from your base in case you blow yourself up. Line up all your ingredients, and just fly through making this thing!

tasks.longDescription: No really, it's totally worth it! You can select an edge of a wall/floor you are building, and if you have items matching that edge in your inventory, it will just place them down for you over a large area. This is great for building out large structures!

quests.name: Introduction To Chisel
quests.description: Chisel is a mod that adds all kinds of decorative blocks. There are some base blocks that can become one of many in a family of blocks by using ... Chisel's chisel. You have to start by making that chisel.

tasks.longDescription: It is iron on a stick. Quite simple. I will give you a chisel you can recharge in a capacitor bank so you can reuse it without it breaking. I honestly think the durability on the chisel is kind of dumb. Like, are people afraid that making a pretty building is over-powered?

quests.name: Konnichiwa!
quests.description: Now you can have your own Japanese-themed garden house. Heck, if you were like me, you probably built pagodas in Vanilla Minecraft any ways. Now you can do it right! There are two families here. One set are flat pieces, since these walls are notorious for being so thin. However, there are also block forms.

tasks.longDescription: You start with a basic paperwall. True to its name, it requires quite a bit of paper.
Put 4 paperwalls in a square in a crafting grid, you can get them in block form.
Use the chisel on them to make these particular blocks!

quests.name: The Industrial Zone
quests.description: This is my favorite block family for no-frills factory labs.

tasks.longDescription: Some stone and iron will make you a small pile of these blocks. If you can't afford the iron to make all the blocks you want, remember that you can use carpenter's blocks to stretch everything for the cost of wood instead.
Right-click with your chisel, send that base block through, and select the one that doesn't have rivets all over it. I like to use that one as girders, and place the riveted ones where they meet.

quests.name: Your Purpled Fantasy
quests.description: Purpled fantasy blocks are really fancy. It's almost offensive to put your ugly machines in them!

tasks.longDescription: The base block is stone surrounding a single gold nugget. The base block looks pretty boring, but some of the variations here are extremely fancy.
Right-click on the chisel with that base block, and you can pick this gold-trimmed block. These are great for caps and corner stones.

quests.name: Jesus Was a Carpenter Too
quests.description: The Carpenter's Blocks mod provides little scaffolds that you can "skin" over with other types of blocks. This lets you very cheaply create elaborate structures. Let's say you wanted to make a castle out of diamond blocks, but you don't want to put down all those diamonds. You could frame the castle out in these blocks, then right click all of them with a diamond block. Each block will take on the appearance of the diamond block.

tasks.longDescription: It just takes a lot of wood to do the big stuff. But, hey, it's renewable. Set up a tree farm if it really bothers you.

quests.name: An Open Door Policy
quests.description: Carpenters' Blocks provides a skinnable door too. My favorite block to use on this is a clear glass block.

tasks.longDescription: The funny thing is that in terms of raw material cost, this door is cheaper to make than a vanilla door!

quests.name: Hammering It Home
quests.description: Use the hammer from Carpenter's Blocks to reconfigure and reorient blocks. This is especially useful for fixing little goofs when laying out slopes. This can change the shape and turn around slopes through various left and right mouse clicks.

tasks.longDescription: Absolutely worth it.

quests.name: Let Me Whitewash, Tom!
quests.description: Thanks to OpenBlocks, you can paint just about anything any color you want. You will need a paint mixer, a paint brush, a bucket of milk and sources for various dyes: red, green, blue, and black. Yes, milk. That is the paint base. You should be happy Minecraft doesn't have smell-o-vision! From there, you can mix it into any other color you want. Then you can slap that color on blocks to your heart's content using your paintbrush.

tasks.longDescription: The mixer recipe is kind of dumb. You need three obsidian and five iron. It could be even more dumb, so just be happy with this. It doesn't require any power or anything, but it does need red, blue, green, and black dyes of some kind. I won't bother checking for them in particular.

And now for the milk ritual. If you actually don't know how this is done, well, that is possible... so you walk up to a cow with an empty bucket, and right click the cow with it. Just like my nephew says, "It's just like real life!"

quests.name: Carving Out A Niche
quests.description: Tinkers' Construct has its own chisel. This one can apply those extra levels of detail on top of a few types of blocks--notably sandstone and regular stone. It is definitely not as elaborate as most of the decorating mods, but it's a quick way to make your first basement base look less ugly. Also, you sometimes need to craft something using chiseled blocks, and this can make them pretty quickly. Some of the crafting grid recipes with it can be interesting too, namely the bricks and the roads.

tasks.longDescription: Chisel head + tool rod
Just make it out of stone. This isn't a tool affected by modifiers, and durability is hardly an issue here. It will probably choke on a stack of items, but it's easy enough to repair.
And now the chisel.

quests.name: Ding Ding Ding Ding Ding
quests.description: Holystone is particularly fun to use as floors because it makes these chiming sounds when you walk across it, and it also emits glowing particles. It doesn't have any other special effects than that, but that's probably enough for you to try them!

tasks.longDescription: Wrap a feather in some stones and you get the base holystone.
Use this chisel to turn the base block into something more interesting.

quests.name: Happy Halloween!
quests.description: Use a chisel on a pumpkin to get different faces. In turn, use a torch on them to get a jack-o-lantern. This gives you some more fun possibilities for your Halloween decorations.

tasks.longDescription: I picked the frowning one. If you get it wrong, you can run it through the chisel again.
Craft it with a torch and it will become lit!

quests.name: A Well-Chiseled Chest
quests.description: If you ever played Minecraft on Christmas, you will find that all the chests are turned into gift boxes. Chisel brought those back for any time of the year, and added on more colors. You just put the chest in a crafting grid with a dye, and you will get a colored gift box.

tasks.longDescription: Use a green dye to make this guy. You probably have some laying around for the spaceship. If not... start looking! You can use cactus green, or combine blue and yellow colors to make green.

quests.name: They Come In Slopes?
quests.description: Now here's a big bombshell in this mod. You can have ramps and slopes! Now you can build a roof to your house that actually looks like a roof!

tasks.longDescription: More wood. Wood wood wood.

quests.name: I Saw The Sign
quests.description: Bibiliocraft has these awesome signs. You can change the font size, alignment, color, among many other things. The editor is a little more versatile than what you get with a Vanilla Minecraft sign too. When you right-click, it will get slapped down blank. You want to shift-right-click it with an empty hand to guarantee bringing up the editor.

tasks.longDescription: It does require a little more resources, but for how many signs you make in a game, it's comparatively simple to post passive-aggressive messages to your base-sharing buddies in style!

quests.name: DecoCraft And Microwaves
quests.description: DecoCraft lets you create all kinds of props that will make you feel at home in Minecraft. It's an essential if you're trying to replicate your house in Minecraft. Most of the stuff you can make are just props, although some things will have some storage in them. You make all of these items out of special dyed clays on a special DecoCraft bench.

tasks.longDescription: You might have to do some more dye hunting to make these clays. If you are extracting them from flowers, I recommend using a pulverizer since you'll get more yield. You need two of each of these colors: red, green, and blue. From there, you can make the crafting clay by combining those dyes with a dirt and a sand. I guess they decided clay is a hard-enough resource to get in Minecraft that it isn't actually used in making... clay. That's fair enough honestly, but the dyes are usually even harder to get!
The bench is made by combining a crafting bench with one each of the three different crafting clays.

From there, search for the microwave in the decobench, feed it the rest of the clay, and you should have yourself a microwave prop! Try to place it. Note that you have a lot of flexibility in orientation. Note: I'm looking for the regular microwave, NOT THE DARK ONE.

quests.name: Something More Concrete
quests.description: Concrete is some great stuff. For the cost of cooking some gravel, you get a block that doubles your speed! However, something about them will keep you from going through doorways, so you need to switch out to another block around 2-block-height passages.

tasks.longDescription: Cook down some gravel in a furnace to make concrete. Note that this has nothing to do with how you make this in real life, just in case you were curious.

You can use the chisel on concrete to get some interesting patterns for sidewalks, but the most-common alternative pattern is asphalt. This is what they use for roads in most parts of the world anyways.

quests.name: I Saw The Wisdom
quests.description: These saws let you get into Forge Microblocks. These let you subdivide regular blocks into all kinds of smaller shapes. The best shape, in my opinion, is the cover. With covers, you can plaster over conduit, pipe, and whatever else and make your base look much more clean.

tasks.longDescription: The idea of a saw made out of stone is really amusing to me, but whatever. You can find out if you like this stuff from making this basic saw. Practice on some wood or cobblestone because it can be fussy first learning how to create the right shapes.

quests.name: I Blacked Out For A Bit
quests.description: Blackout curtains halve the amount of light passing through them. The most common use for these is to black out an area for a monster farm. People like to set up glass rooms for their monster farms so they can see what is happening, but the glass lets light through, preventing the monsters from spawning. Blackout curtains help here.

tasks.longDescription: I'll reimburse your wool if you craft this.

quests.name: It's Downright Heavenly
quests.description: The Angel Block can be placed anywhere in space without being attached to something. This is useful for setting up an island in the middle of the ocean, or well, an island in the middle of the air. Other blocks can then be built off of it to create the structure you wish to have.

tasks.longDescription: It seems like a dumb thing, but it sure beats nerdpoles. You know, when you just jump up over and over while building blocks underneath you into the heavens.

quests.name: Read This Building Guide
quests.description: The Building Guide will set out a template for various shapes. You can set the sizes it should use in all dimensions. This makes it much easier to do things like domes and spheres.

tasks.description: It's Really Easy To Make Too
tasks.longDescription: Glass and torches... etc.

quests.name: Am I Clear?
quests.description: There are two very important clear glass blocks for decoration. The smeltery can produce Clear Glass, and the EnderIO alloy smelter can product Quite Clear Glass. They are generally interchangeable.

tasks.longDescription: They combine into larger structures very well. Most importantly, they don't shatter when you break them!

quests.name: Oh This Is A Great Thing!
quests.description: Maybe you have outgrown your base, or it's just driving you nuts. If you just want to blow it all to smithereens, then obsidian TNT is for you. This has a huge blast radius. You want to stay well clear of it. Note that you will lose most of the stuff it blows up. You want to gut your base before resorting to this!

tasks.longDescription: No really, it blows up pretty big.

quests.name: Torch It Up
quests.description: Yeap, you guessed it: torches can be skinned too!

tasks.longDescription: Charcoal/coal plus one carpenter's block. Z...z...z...

quests.name: Random Illumination
quests.description: Any Carpenter's Block can be self-illuminating if you give it some glowstone. If you have a big room, this is one way to light up parts of it without having to outright place a lamp or torch.

tasks.longDescription: I can't check that you did this in the quest book since this all happens in-world, so scout's honor, okay?

quests.name: A Bright Idea
quests.description: You can chisel torches! This turns them all kinds of shapes that might make better sense in your base than random flaming sticks.

tasks.longDescription: Torch in, bulb out.

quests.name: Oh Hey, Another Chisel!
quests.description: This chisel lets you overlay textures over some existing carpenter's blocks. There are just a handful of them. That being said, I find I like the vertical wavy pattern to make a roof appear corrugated.

tasks.longDescription: Chisel chisel chisel chisel chisel...

quests.name: A Bench Worth Warming
quests.description: This bench lets you create a variety of elaborate furniture, decorations, and ... kind of stinky weapons. It's a good way to flush out your base. Right click the "..." that shows up in its menu to see all the stuff you can make.

quests.name: Let Me Stencil You In
quests.description: You can apply different textures to your paint. Using these stencils cleverly, you can have multiple colors in stripes and bands, or just allow some of the original material to shine through. You right click the stencil on the wall, then paint over it, and the unblocked parts of the stencil will be the only parts painted. So if you get one offset of vertical stripes, you can paint one band of stripes, switch the stencil, and paint the other band of stripes.

tasks.longDescription: The drawing table creates patterned stencils from the base stencil. So you'll need something like three stencils: two for the table, and one to change.
Okay I'll fess up. I picked the heart pattern because it was pretty obvious. I'll give you plenty of blanks to do whatever other ones you want.

quests.name: Dyeing To Get These
quests.description: What a pain in the butt it is to hunt down flowers for dyes! Well, if you have fistfuls of bonemeal, just spray grass outside with it. You'll get a bunch of tall grass, but some flowers here and there. That should help you get some of these flowers. If you need more than that, set up a harvester in a grassy patch getting fed water from a sprinkler.

tasks.longDescription: Blablabla flowers. If you need lots of bonemeal, it's time to set up a mob farm. See the post-scarcity chapter for setting up a grinder. You could just set up a dark space near your base with a small hole and just punch into it from time to time, but it's tedious, and you still get bopped by the monsters sometimes.

quests.name: Canvasing For OpenBlocks
quests.description: When you start painting stuff in OpenBlocks, it turns the blocks into canvas blocks. This can be a problem if you are using expensive blocks. Here's a better idea: use canvas. It'll eat paper alive to make it in bulk, but that's a problem you can solve too with farming.

tasks.longDescription: 8 paper and a fence for 9 canvas. I'll give you a lot of canvas and paper for the fuss.
